Unity and Resilience: President Biden Calls for Americans to Come Together to Overcome Challenges

My fellow Americans,

Today, I stand before you humbled and honored to take the oath of office as the 46th President of the United States. As I begin this new chapter in our nation's story, I am reminded of the power of democracy and the resilience of the American people.

We stand at a crossroads in our history, with challenges that threaten our very way of life. The COVID-19 pandemic has taken a devastating toll on our communities, our economy, and our collective psyche. We have faced divisions and discord that have shaken the foundations of our democracy. But in the face of these challenges, we must remember that we are not alone.

We stand on the shoulders of generations of Americans who have fought for the rights and freedoms that we hold dear. We stand on the foundation of a democracy that has endured through the test of time, a democracy that has prevailed despite the forces that seek to undermine it.

As I take this oath, I am mindful of the precedents that have come before me. I salute the leadership and legacy of my predecessors, including Jimmy Carter, who has dedicated his life to public service and whose commitment to democracy and human rights has inspired us all.

But today, we must look to the future. We must come together as a nation to overcome the challenges that we face. We must reject a culture of manipulated facts and embrace the truth that will set us free. We must treat each other with dignity and respect, regardless of our political beliefs or affiliations.

As President, I pledge to be a leader for all Americans. I will work tirelessly to address the crises that threaten our nation, from the COVID-19 pandemic to economic struggles, racial injustice, climate change, and political extremism. I will do so with unity and determination, knowing that together, we can overcome any obstacle.

Unity is the path forward. It is the only way that we can heal our divisions and build a brighter future for ourselves and for generations to come. It is the only way that we can overcome the forces of manipulation and lies that seek to undermine our democracy.

But unity is not a destination; it is a journey. It requires effort and commitment from each and every one of us. It requires us to listen to each other, to hear each other's voices, and to work together towards a common goal.

So let us begin this journey together, with hope and resilience in our hearts. Let us reject the forces of division and embrace the power of unity. Let us stand together as one people, united in our commitment to democracy and to each other.

Together, we can overcome any challenge. Together, we can build a brighter future for ourselves and for generations to come. Together, we can make America great again, not just for some, but for all.

Thank you, and may God bless America.

Fact Check: Inauguration Day Limitations and Misinformation

As Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th President of the United States, the inauguration ceremony faced unprecedented limitations due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and recent security threats. Despite these challenges, the event marked a significant moment in American history, with strict coronavirus precautions in place to ensure the safety of attendees. However, misinformation surrounding the event has been rampant, with some claims receiving a rating of "missing context."

Limited Crowd Sizes

One of the most notable aspects of the inauguration was the limited crowd size due to the ongoing pandemic. In an effort to prevent the spread of COVID-19, attendees were required to wear masks and maintain social distancing. As a result, the ceremony was significantly less crowded than previous inaugurations.

Former President Trump's Absence

Another notable absence at the inauguration was that of former President Donald Trump, who did not attend the ceremony. This marked a significant change from previous inaugurations, where outgoing presidents have traditionally attended the swearing-in of their successors.

Heightened Security Measures

Washington D.C. experienced heightened security measures following a pro-Trump riot earlier in the month. As a result, the area surrounding the National Mall was closed to the public, and attendees were subject to extensive security screenings.

Misinformation Surrounding the Inauguration

Despite the significance of the event, misinformation surrounding the 2020 election and Inauguration Day has been prevalent. False claims have circulated, including the notion that flags were added to the National Mall to make the inauguration look less empty.

Public Art Exhibition

In fact, the flags that were present on the National Mall were part of a public art exhibition representing Americans unable to attend the inauguration due to COVID-19. The exhibition, titled "We the People," featured over 190,000 flags representing the estimated 190,000 people who were unable to attend the ceremony due to the pandemic.

Biden's Inauguration Continues Strict Coronavirus Precautions

Despite the limitations, Biden's inauguration maintained strict coronavirus precautions, continuing practices from his presidential campaign. This included the use of masks, social distancing, and extensive security measures.

A Significant Change from Traditional Inauguration Ceremonies

The absence of large crowds marks a significant change from traditional inaugurations, where crowds of thousands have been the norm. However, the limitations were necessary to ensure the safety of attendees and prevent the spread of COVID-19.

Claim Rated as Missing Context

The claim that flags were used to fill space was rated as missing context due to the pandemic and security measures. While the exhibition was intended to represent those unable to attend, it was also a poignant reminder of the challenges faced during the inauguration.

The Significance of the Inauguration

Despite the limitations, the inauguration was a significant moment in American history, marking the peaceful transfer of power and the beginning of a new era in the country's leadership.

The Importance of Accurate Information

In times of misinformation, it is crucial to rely on credible sources and fact-check claims to ensure accuracy. The inauguration of Joe Biden serves as a reminder of the importance of accurate information and the need to verify claims before sharing them.

The Future of Inauguration Ceremonies

As the COVID-19 pandemic continues to impact events around the world, it remains to be seen how future inaugurations will be affected. However, the Biden inauguration serves as a model for how to navigate these challenges while maintaining the integrity and significance of the event.

The Role of Social Media in Misinformation

Social media has played a significant role in the dissemination of misinformation surrounding the inauguration. It is essential to be cautious when sharing information on social media and to verify claims before sharing them.

The Importance of Fact-Checking

Fact-checking is crucial in ensuring the accuracy of information, particularly during significant events like the inauguration. By verifying claims and providing context, fact-checking can help to prevent the spread of misinformation.

The Impact of Misinformation on Society

Misinformation can have a significant impact on society, leading to confusion, mistrust, and division. It is essential to be aware of the potential for misinformation and to take steps to verify claims before sharing them.

The Need for Responsible Journalism

As journalists, it is essential to be responsible and to verify claims before sharing them. By doing so, journalists can help to prevent the spread of misinformation and promote a more informed public discourse.

The Importance of Accurate Reporting

Accurate reporting is crucial in ensuring that the public has a clear understanding of significant events like the inauguration. By verifying claims and providing context, journalists can help to promote a more informed public discourse.

Biden Inaugurated as 46th President of the United States, Vows to Lead for 'All Americans'

Washington CNN – January 20, 2021

Joe Biden was inaugurated as the 46th President of the United States on Wednesday, taking the oath of office with heightened security and COVID-19 precautions in place. The ceremony, which took place on the West Front of the U.S. Capitol, was attended by Biden's family, Vice President Kamala Harris, and Congressional leaders, as well as former presidents and first ladies.

In his inaugural address, Biden pledged to be a "president for all Americans," saying, "My fellow Americans, the American story is one of the most improbable in history. It's a story about how a nation of farmers and factory workers, of immigrants and innovators, could come together to build the greatest nation on Earth."

Biden was sworn in by Chief Justice John Roberts using a family Bible, and he signed his first presidential documents, including an Inauguration Day Proclamation and nominations.

Former President Donald Trump left the White House for the last time on Wednesday morning, expressing it was a "great honor" to serve. Trump spoke at Joint Base Andrews, thanking his family and chief of staff, and wishing the incoming administration "great luck" without naming Biden.

Vice President Harris made history as the first female, first Black, and first South Asian vice president of the United States. She attended morning services at Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle with her family and Congressional leaders.

The inauguration featured performances by Lady Gaga, Jennifer Lopez, Garth Brooks, and poet Amanda Gorman.

Biden signed over a dozen executive actions targeting Trump's legacy, including one that reverses the travel ban targeting predominantly Muslim countries. He emphasized respect among White House staff, saying, "We will respect the dignity of work and the worth of every American."

In a wreath-laying ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery, Biden and Harris participated with former presidents, including Barack Obama and Bill Clinton.

Biden also addressed the nation in a prime-time address, saying, "We are in a battle for the soul of America. But I promise you, we will be a government of, by, and for the people."

  • "We will respect the dignity of work and the worth of every American."
  • "We are in a battle for the soul of America. But I promise you, we will be a government of, by, and for the people."

Quoting Former President Trump:

  • "It was a great honor to serve."
  • "I wish the incoming administration great luck."

Quoting Vice President Harris:

  • "I am honored to serve as the first female, first Black, and first South Asian vice president of the United States."

He emphasized respect among White House staff, saying, "We will respect the dignity of work and the worth of every American." In a wreath-laying ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery, Biden and Harris participated with former presidents, including Barack Obama and Bill Clinton. Biden Inaugurated as 46th President, Calls for Unity in Face of Challenges

WASHINGTON (AP) – Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th president of the United States on Wednesday, emphasizing democracy's triumph and calling for unity in the face of numerous challenges facing the nation.

Biden, a Democrat, took the oath of office during a ceremony at the U.S. Capitol, where heightened security measures were in place due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the recent siege on the Capitol building. In his inaugural address, Biden emphasized the importance of coming together as a nation to address issues such as the pandemic, economic strain, and racial injustice.

"This is a day of celebration, reflection, and recommitment," Biden said. "Today, we mark the triumph of democracy over chaos, of hope over despair."

Biden's inauguration was notable for several reasons, including the absence of crowds due to the pandemic and the presence of a large security force. Over 200,000 American flags were planted on the National Mall to represent those who couldn't attend the inauguration.

Kamala Harris, a Democrat and the first woman, first Black person, and first person of South Asian descent elected to the vice presidency, also took the oath of office alongside Biden. Former Presidents Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, and Barack Obama attended the inauguration, highlighting bipartisan support for the new administration.

Biden entered office with a plan for an ambitious first 100 days, focusing on combating the pandemic and economic relief. He signed a series of executive actions on his first day, including rejoining the Paris Climate Accords and instituting a mask mandate on federal property.

The inauguration ceremony included performances by Lady Gaga and others, with a focus on national unity and healing. The absence of crowds and the presence of a large security force marked this as an unusual inauguration, but Biden and his supporters were undeterred, emphasizing the importance of democracy and the peaceful transfer of power.

"This is a moment of hope and renewal," Biden said. "A moment that proves America is still a beacon of democracy, a beacon of hope, for the world."

Amanda Gorman's Inaugural Poem: A Call to Unity and Resilience

Amanda Gorman, the nation's first-ever youth poet laureate, captivated the audience at President Joe Biden's inauguration with her powerful and inspiring poem, 'The Hill We Climb.' The poem addressed themes of hope, unity, and resilience in the face of adversity, reflecting on the challenges the United States has faced and envisioning a future of improvement and inclusivity.

Gorman's poem evoked the image of a "skinny Black girl descended from slaves and raised by a single mother," dreaming of presidential aspirations, emphasizing progress and representation. The poem underscored the importance of coming together to overcome differences and build a better future, invoking the notion of the United States as a nation that is "not broken, but simply unfinished."

Through her poem, Gorman highlighted the power of unity and the potential for change that comes from collective action and understanding. Her delivery and the content of her poem were widely praised for their inspiration and poise during a significant historical moment. The recitation of 'The Hill We Climb' at the inauguration marked a symbolic moment of hope and renewal for many Americans.

In her poem, Gorman encouraged resilience and unity, echoing the themes of President Biden's inauguration. She called for continued effort towards perfection, recognizing that the United States is a nation that is constantly striving to improve and become a better version of itself.

Through 'The Hill We Climb,' Gorman reminded the audience that the United States is a nation of immigrants, with a rich history of diversity and inclusivity. She emphasized the importance of recognizing and valuing the contributions of all individuals, regardless of their race, ethnicity, or background.

Gorman's poem also addressed the challenges faced by marginalized communities, including systemic racism and inequality. She called for a more equitable and just society, where everyone has access to the same opportunities and resources.

Through her powerful and moving poem, Amanda Gorman reminded the nation of the importance of hope, unity, and resilience in the face of adversity. Her recitation of 'The Hill We Climb' at President Biden's inauguration was a fitting tribute to the American spirit and a call to action for a brighter future.

Trump Snubs Inauguration, Breaking Tradition and Raising Concerns About Democracy

WASHINGTON (AP) – In a stunning move that has raised concerns about the future of democracy, President Donald Trump announced on Tuesday that he will not attend President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration on January 20. This decision breaks the tradition of a peaceful transition of power and is seen as an act of defiance by Trump, who has continued to falsely claim that he won the election and has alleged widespread voter fraud.

Biden, who has been critical of Trump's actions in his final days in office, agreed with Trump's decision, calling him an "embarrassment" and saying it's a "good thing." Former Presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush, and Bill Clinton, except for the ailing Jimmy Carter, will attend Biden's inauguration, signaling their support for the democratic transition of power.

Trump's announcement came amidst discussions of his second impeachment and after he was banned from Twitter for inciting violence. The President has continued to make false claims about the election and has shown no signs of accepting defeat. Vice President Mike Pence's attendance at the inauguration is still uncertain, although Biden has welcomed him.

Historian Douglas Brinkley suggested that Trump's absence from the inauguration portrays him as a "sore loser" and undermines democracy. "It's a sad day for America when the President refuses to acknowledge the will of the people and the peaceful transfer of power," Brinkley said. "This is not how democracy is supposed to work, and it sets a dangerous precedent for the future."

Sen. Rick Scott (R-Fla.) also expressed concerns about Trump's actions, saying, "The President's decision to skip the inauguration is unprecedented and troubling. It's important that the President respect the democratic process and the will of the American people."

Devin O'Malley, spokesperson for Vice President Pence, declined to comment on the Vice President's attendance at the inauguration. Judd Deere, White House spokesperson, also declined to comment.

Discussions about invoking the 25th Amendment or impeachment are ongoing amidst concerns about Trump's actions in his final days. Some lawmakers have called for the President to be removed from office due to his refusal to accept defeat and his continued efforts to undermine the democratic process.

In conclusion, Trump's decision to skip the inauguration has raised concerns about the future of democracy and the peaceful transfer of power. As the country prepares for a new administration, it is important that the President respect the will of the people and the democratic process.

FBI Warns of Armed Protests Ahead of Biden Inauguration, National Guard Deployed in Multiple States

As President-elect Joe Biden prepares to take office on January 20, the FBI has issued warnings of possible armed protests in all 50 states and the US capital, leading to the deployment of National Guard forces in several states. Wesley Allen Beeler, a 34-year-old man from Virginia, was arrested at a security checkpoint near the US Capitol with a loaded handgun and over 500 rounds of ammunition, claiming it was an "honest mistake" and that he was a private security guard who got lost.

State officials are taking various security measures, including closing the Texas Capitol and erecting a fence around the Michigan Capitol, in response to the potential violent protests. Thousands of armed National Guard troops are on the streets of Washington, DC, ahead of the inauguration. Democratic leaders of four US congressional committees have opened a review of the January 6 riot at the US Capitol.

"We are taking all necessary precautions to ensure the safety of everyone involved in the inauguration," said Steve McCraw, Director of the Texas Department of Public Safety. "We will not tolerate any acts of violence or intimidation."

Michigan State Police Director Joe Gasper echoed these sentiments, stating, "We are working closely with federal and local authorities to ensure the safety of everyone at the inauguration. We will do everything in our power to prevent any acts of violence."

In Illinois, Governor JB Pritzker declared a state of emergency ahead of the inauguration, citing concerns about the potential for violence. "We will not allow any acts of terrorism or violence to disrupt the peaceful transfer of power," he said.

Democratic US Representative Don Beyer of Virginia expressed concern about the potential for violence, stating, "We are deeply troubled by the reports of armed protests and the potential for violence at the inauguration. We urge everyone to remain calm and peaceful, and to respect the democratic process."

House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff and House Homeland Security Chairman Bennie Thompson called for a thorough investigation into the January 6 riot at the US Capitol, stating, "We must get to the bottom of this incident and ensure that it does not happen again. The safety of our elected officials and the integrity of our democratic process are of the utmost importance."

House Oversight Chairwoman Carolyn Maloney echoed these sentiments, stating, "We will not tolerate any acts of violence or intimidation against our elected officials. We will do everything in our power to ensure their safety and the integrity of our democratic process."

House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler called for increased security measures ahead of the inauguration, stating, "We must take all necessary precautions to ensure the safety of everyone involved in the inauguration. We will not allow any acts of violence or intimidation to undermine the rule of law and the democratic process."

In conclusion, the FBI's warnings of possible armed protests ahead of President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration have led to the deployment of National Guard forces in multiple states and a review of the January 6 riot at the US Capitol. State officials are taking various security measures to ensure the safety of everyone involved in the inauguration, and Democratic leaders are calling for a thorough investigation into the incident. The safety and integrity of our democratic process are of the utmost importance, and we must take all necessary precautions to ensure that these values are upheld.

Inauguration Uncertainty: Fears of MAGA Violence and QAnon Disruptions as Biden Takes Office

As Joe Biden prepares to take the oath of office, the nation's capital is bracing for potential violence and disruptions during the inauguration. In response, the Pentagon is intensifying efforts to eliminate far-right extremists from its ranks. Two Army National Guard members with ties to fringe right-wing militias were removed from the inauguration security mission.

"A healthy democracy does not need a division-size force to safeguard the incoming president in its capital," underscores the deep democratic issues at play. As the nation prepares for the transfer of power, the focus is on ensuring the safety and security of the event, while also addressing the underlying issues that have led to this heightened level of tension and violence.

Biden Inaugurated as 46th President of the United States, Vows to Heal a Divided Nation

Washington D.C. - Joe Biden was inaugurated as the 46th President of the United States on Wednesday, vowing to heal a divided nation and restore the country's commitment to democratic values. Biden, 78, took the oath of office with a family heirloom Bible, pledging to uphold the Constitution and protect the rights of all Americans.

In a scaled-back ceremony due to COVID-19 and security concerns, Biden became the oldest US president in history, succeeding Donald Trump, who broke tradition by not attending the inauguration nor meeting with his successor. Top Republicans and former Presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush, and Bill Clinton were in attendance, while Jimmy Carter abstained due to COVID-19.

Kamala Harris, the first Black, first woman, and first Asian American to hold the vice presidency, was sworn in by Justice Sonia Sotomayor, using two Bibles including one owned by Thurgood Marshall. Harris's historic inauguration marked a significant moment in American history, as the country continues to grapple with political divide, economic turmoil, and a devastating pandemic.

The National Mall was filled with nearly 200,000 flags and 56 pillars of light to represent the 50 states and territories of the United States. The inauguration took place under increased security measures, with thousands of National Guard troops deployed following the January 6 Capitol siege.

Biden's inaugural address emphasized the need to heal the country's political divisions, protect the rights of all Americans, and address the pressing issues facing the nation, including the COVID-19 pandemic and economic inequality. "This is our moment to turn the page on the bitter past," Biden said. "To put the grievances of the past behind us, and to come together as a nation to heal."

As the 46th President of the United States, Biden inherits a nation in turmoil, with deep political divisions, a struggling economy, and a global pandemic that has claimed millions of lives worldwide. But in his inaugural address, Biden offered a message of hope and unity, urging Americans to come together to address the challenges facing the nation. "We will get through this," he said. "We will get through this together."

Dignitaries Gather for Biden's Inauguration as Nation Turns the Page on Trump Era

WASHINGTON – As the nation turns the page on the Trump era, dignitaries have gathered at the U.S. Capitol for Joe Biden's inauguration. Former presidents, lawmakers, and governors have arrived for the ceremony, which is taking place on a chilly but sunny day with the U.S. Marine Band playing.

Invited guests are seated in widely spaced chairs for COVID-19 safety, surrounded by security measures. Former President Barack Obama and South Carolina Rep. James Clyburn were seen greeting each other, while Congressional leaders and other notable figures have taken their places on the platform.

Alex Rodriguez, who is set to perform at the ceremony, was spotted arriving at the Capitol. Meanwhile, Donald Trump is the first departing commander-in-chief since 1869 to skip his successor's swearing-in. Vice President Mike Pence and former President George W. Bush are among the Republicans in attendance, while former President Jimmy Carter is the only former president not participating in the ceremony.

Former GOP senator Jeff Flake commented on the importance of the peaceful transfer of power and Biden's presidency. "It's a momentous day for our country, and I'm honored to be here to witness the peaceful transfer of power," Flake said. "Joe Biden has a big task ahead of him, but I have faith that he will lead our country with integrity and compassion. It's a new chapter for our nation, and I'm excited to see what the future holds."

As the ceremony gets underway, the nation is bidding farewell to the Trump era and welcoming a new leader who has promised to heal the country's divisions and restore its global standing. The mood is somber, but there is also a sense of hope and optimism as the country turns the page on a tumultuous period in its history.

Lady Gaga's Favorite Inauguration Look: A Bulletproof Schiaparelli Haute Couture Dress

Lady Gaga, the multihyphenate star known for her bold fashion choices, has revealed that the Schiaparelli Haute Couture dress she wore to President Joe Biden's inauguration is one of her favorite outfits. The stunning gown, which featured a giant gilded brooch in the shape of a dove, symbolizing peace, was a personal choice for Gaga, reflecting her Italian-American heritage.

"I wanted to wear something that was not only beautiful but also meaningful," Gaga said in a statement. "Choosing Schiaparelli was a way for me to connect with my roots and pay tribute to the rich cultural heritage of Italy and America."

The dress, designed by Maison Schiaparelli's current creative director, Daniel Roseberry, was a love letter to America, celebrating Gaga's artistry and creativity. "I wanted to create something that would make people feel proud and inspired," Roseberry said. "Lady Gaga is an icon, and it was an honor to dress her for such an important occasion."

Gaga's outfit for the inauguration included a white cape by Givenchy before the event, which fans likened to Princess Leia's iconic look. For the singing performance, she wore a fitted navy cashmere jacket and a voluminous washed red silk faille skirt. Her hair was styled in a braid, similar to the previous day, but accented with a red flower.

Roseberry, who is American, ties the French brand Schiaparelli back to the U.S. with his background. "I want to bring Schiaparelli back to its American roots," he said. "Lady Gaga is the perfect embodiment of that vision."

In a British Vogue video highlighting 20 of the most iconic looks Gaga has worn throughout her career, the Schiaparelli dress was prominently featured. Gaga revealed that the dress was bulletproof, adding an extra layer of significance to the already stunning outfit.

"I wanted to make a statement, not just with my fashion choices, but with my message of peace and unity," Gaga said. "The Schiaparelli dress was the perfect way to do that."

Inauguration Rehearsal Lockdown: Precautionary Measure or Coincidence?

Washington D.C. - In a surprise turn of events, the US Capitol complex was temporarily locked down during a rehearsal for President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration on Wednesday. The lockdown was initiated by the acting chief of Capitol Police, citing a fire in a nearby homeless encampment as the reason for the precautionary measure.

According to officials, the fire, which occurred approximately 1.6 kilometers away from the Capitol, raised security concerns and prompted the evacuation and lockdown. While there was no immediate threat to the public or the inauguration, the acting chief of Capitol Police took the necessary measures to ensure the safety of everyone involved in the rehearsal.

President-elect Joe Biden was not present at the rehearsal during the lockdown. The lockdown follows heightened security measures due to the January 6 riot at the US Capitol, and security in and around the Capitol has been increased, with the area being on high alert and lockdown.

Participants of the rehearsal, including a military band, were directed to move to a secure location inside the Capitol complex. The US Secret Service announced on Twitter that the lockdown was a precautionary measure, confirming there was no public threat. The fire department extinguished the fire near the Capitol, confirming there were no injuries and explaining the source of the smoke seen.

The incident has raised questions about the timing of the lockdown and whether it was a coincidence or a precautionary measure. While the acting chief of Capitol Police has stated that there was no immediate threat to the public or the inauguration, the incident has highlighted the ongoing concerns about security in the nation's capital.

As the inauguration of President-elect Joe Biden approaches, security measures will continue to be a top priority. The lockdown at the US Capitol complex serves as a reminder of the ongoing efforts to ensure the safety of everyone involved in the inauguration.

In conclusion, the temporary lockdown at the US Capitol complex during a rehearsal for President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration was a precautionary measure taken by the acting chief of Capitol Police. While there was no immediate threat to the public or the inauguration, the incident highlights the ongoing concerns about security in the nation's capital. The lockdown serves as a reminder of the ongoing efforts to ensure the safety of everyone involved in the inauguration.

Inauguration Security: Thousands of National Guard Members Deployed, FBI Warns of Extremist Threats

Washington CNN – As President-elect Joe Biden prepares to take office, more than 20,000 National Guard members are expected to be deployed in Washington, D.C. to secure the inauguration, according to officials. This number exceeds the number of active-duty US troops in Afghanistan, Iraq, and Syria combined.

"We are taking every precaution to ensure the safety and security of everyone involved in the inauguration," Wray said in a statement. "We are working closely with our partners in law enforcement and the military to identify and disrupt any potential threats."

Washington, D.C. Police Chief Robert Contee has also expressed concerns about the possibility of violence, particularly in light of the recent breach of the US Capitol. "We are taking this situation very seriously and are working closely with our federal partners to ensure the safety of everyone involved," Contee said.

Ken Cuccinelli, a senior official at the Department of Homeland Security, confirmed that discussions are underway about possibly raising the national terror threat level. "We are constantly monitoring the situation and will take whatever steps are necessary to ensure the safety of the American people," Cuccinelli said.

The Secret Service has expanded security perimeters around the Capitol, White House, and National Naval Observatory, with the help of the National Guard and other law enforcement agencies. The total request for National Guard support is close to 30,000, with an expected final need of approximately 20,000.

"This is an unprecedented level of security for an inauguration," said a senior military official. "We are taking every precaution to ensure the safety of everyone involved, including the President-elect, the Vice President-elect, and the thousands of guests who will be attending the inauguration."

As the inauguration approaches, officials are urging the public to remain vigilant and to report any suspicious activity to law enforcement. "We are working closely with our partners in law enforcement to identify and disrupt any potential threats," Wray said. "We urge the public to remain vigilant and to report any suspicious activity to the authorities immediately."

In conclusion, the security measures in place for the inauguration are unprecedented, with thousands of National Guard members deployed and federal law enforcement agencies working closely with the Secret Service to ensure the safety of everyone involved. As the inauguration approaches, officials are urging the public to remain vigilant and to report any suspicious activity to law enforcement.

Biden Inauguration Passes Without Incident, Security Efforts Hailed as Success

WASHINGTON (AP) – In an unprecedented security effort, Joe Biden was safely sworn in as the 46th President of the United States on Wednesday, with no major security incidents reported despite heightened concerns about far-right extremist and militia groups.

Gen. Daniel Hokanson, chief of the National Guard Bureau, praised the efforts of the 25,000 National Guard members deployed for the inauguration, saying, "Their professionalism and dedication to duty were on full display today. We are proud to have played a role in ensuring the safety and security of this historic event."

Security concerns were heightened following a previous attack by rioters loyal to Donald Trump on the U.S. Capitol in January, and law enforcement agencies monitored far-right extremist and militia groups for potential threats. Despite the heavy security presence and the closure of the National Mall with extensive checkpoints, there were only a few scattered arrests and no major protests.

The FBI vetted all 25,000 National Guard members in an unprecedented security effort, and 12 members were removed from their duties due to extremist statements or ties to right-wing militias.

Online, followers of the QAnon conspiracy theory expressed disappointment that their theories did not materialize, with one user tweeting, "Another failed prediction from the QAnon cult. #Disappointed #InaugurationDay"

The security effort in Washington, D.C., is expected to remain heightened for several days post-inauguration, with law enforcement agencies continuing to monitor potential threats.

The decision was made at the ECB's latest monetary policy meeting, where the Governing Council unanimously agreed to recalibrate the bank's asset purchase program.

According to ECB President Christine Lagarde, the decision to reduce asset purchases is a "recalibration" rather than tapering, echoing similar stances taken by other central banks. The Pandemic Emergency Purchase Program (PEPP) will see a "moderately lower" pace of net asset purchases, continuing at least until March 2022, with a balance level maintained at least until the end of 2023. Other ECB programs, such as the Targeted Longer-Term Refinancing Operations (TLTRO III) and the Asset Purchase Program (APP), will continue as planned.

Central banks globally agree that QE programs need to end before interest rates can be hiked to avoid disrupting the yield curve. However, the Federal Reserve is still expanding its balance sheet by $120 billion a month, despite consensus on the need to start tapering this year.

"Today's decision reflects the progress made in the Eurozone's economic recovery," Lagarde said in a statement. "As the economy continues to grow and inflation remains subdued, it is appropriate to recalibrate our asset purchase program to maintain price stability and support the recovery."

Lagarde emphasized that the ECB's decision to reduce asset purchases does not signal a tightening of monetary policy, as interest rates are expected to remain at their present levels for an extended period. The ECB President also noted that the bank will continue to monitor economic developments closely and adjust its policies as needed.

The ECB's decision to recalibrate its asset purchase program comes as other major central banks have already started tapering or ending their QE programs. The Bank of Japan, Bank of Canada, Bank of England, Reserve Bank of New Zealand, and Reserve Bank of Australia have all taken similar steps in recent months.

In conclusion, the ECB's decision to recalibrate its asset purchase program is a significant step towards normalizing monetary policy in the Eurozone. While the bank remains committed to supporting the economic recovery, it is clear that QE programs need to end before interest rates can be hiked to avoid disrupting the yield curve. As central banks globally continue to navigate the complex process of exiting QE, the ECB's decision serves as a reminder of the challenges and opportunities that lie ahead.

Fact Check: Bill Clinton Not Poisoned to Death at Guantanamo Bay, Despite False Social Media Claims

It is worth noting that Real Raw News has a disclaimer stating its content contains humor, parody, and satire, but this is hidden on the about page. Despite this, fact-checking investigation by PolitiFact attributes these stories to Michael Ruffin, who uses the pseudonym Michael Baxter and defends the accuracy of his stories despite the satire disclaimer.

In conclusion, the claim that Bill Clinton was poisoned to death at Guantanamo Bay is entirely false and unsubstantiated. Fact Check: GOP Leaders Falsely Blame Biden for Rising Gas, Lumber Prices

FDA Authorizes AstraZeneca's Evusheld for Pre-Exposure COVID-19 Prevention in Certain Individuals

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued an emergency use authorization (EUA) for AstraZeneca's Evusheld for the pre-exposure prevention of COVID-19 in certain individuals, the agency announced today. This authorization is for adults and pediatric individuals 12 years of age and older weighing at least 40 kilograms (~88 pounds) who are not currently infected with SARS-CoV-2, not recently exposed to it, and either immunocompromised or have a history of severe adverse reactions to COVID-19 vaccines.

"While vaccination remains the most effective way to prevent COVID-19, we recognize that there are certain individuals who may benefit from alternative prevention measures," said Patrizia Cavazzoni, M.D., Director of the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research. "The authorization of Evusheld provides another tool in the fight against COVID-19, particularly for those who may be at higher risk of severe illness from the virus."

Evusheld is a combination of two monoclonal antibodies, tixagevimab and cilgavimab, and is designed for a six-month efficacy period. The treatment is administered via two consecutive intramuscular injections, but it is not a substitute for vaccination. The FDA emphasizes that vaccination remains recommended for those eligible, as it is the most effective way to prevent COVID-19.

The EUA for Evusheld is based on the results of the PROVENT clinical trial, which showed a 77% reduced risk of developing COVID-19 for Evusheld recipients over those receiving a placebo. Common side effects of Evusheld include hypersensitivity reactions, bleeding at the injection site, headache, fatigue, cough, and in rare cases, serious cardiac adverse events.

"Monoclonal antibodies in Evusheld work by blocking the virus by targeting the spike protein, which is critical for SARS-CoV-2 to infect cells," said Dr. Cavazzoni. "This mechanism of action provides a different approach to preventing COVID-19 than vaccination, and we believe it has the potential to be an important tool in the fight against the virus."

The FDA has carefully evaluated the safety and effectiveness of Evusheld and has determined that it meets the criteria for an EUA. The agency will continue to monitor the safety and effectiveness of Evusheld as it is used to prevent COVID-19.

In conclusion, the FDA's authorization of Evusheld for pre-exposure COVID-19 prevention in certain individuals provides another tool in the fight against the virus. While vaccination remains the most effective way to prevent COVID-19, this alternative prevention measure may be beneficial for those who may be at higher risk of severe illness from the virus. Ever Given Grounding Sparks Legal and Insurance Disputes Under General Average Principles

The incident has raised questions about the shared responsibility between vessel owners and cargo interests, and the potential impact on consumer prices.

Facebook Outage Highlights Vulnerabilities in Internet Infrastructure

On Monday, Facebook experienced a massive outage that affected not only its own services but also those of its subsidiaries, including Instagram and WhatsApp. The outage was initially attributed to issues with Border Gateway Protocol (BGP), a critical system that directs internet traffic. However, as it turns out, the root cause of the outage was a maintenance error that took down connections to Facebook's data centers, rather than primarily BGP.

BGP is likened to a map that guides data packets across various autonomous systems to reach their destination efficiently. The internet is divided into autonomous systems, such as internet service providers (ISPs), companies, or governments, and BGP helps navigate data through these systems. Errors in BGP can misroute traffic, similar to outdated or wrong directions on a map leading drivers astray.

In the case of Facebook's outage, the cause was linked to a "configuration change on the backbone routers," leading to a cascading communication failure between data centers. Facebook has its own BGP system for fast updates within its data centers, but the outage was more about internal communication than external routing.

DNS (Domain Name System) works alongside BGP, identifying the IP address, while BGP finds the best route to that address. Past BGP mishaps include ISPs accidentally hijacking traffic or causing global access issues to sites like YouTube.

The Facebook incident highlights the vulnerabilities in internet infrastructure and the potential for disruptions to critical services. While BGP is a crucial system, it is not foolproof, and maintenance errors can still cause significant problems. As the internet continues to grow and evolve, it is essential to address these vulnerabilities and ensure that critical services are protected from disruptions.

In conclusion, the Facebook outage serves as a reminder of the complexities of internet infrastructure and the potential for disruptions to critical services. While BGP is a critical system, it is not the only factor that can cause issues. Maintenance errors, like the one that caused Facebook's outage, can also have a significant impact. As the internet continues to evolve, it is essential to address these vulnerabilities and ensure that critical services are protected from disruptions.

Under state law, Chauvin will only be sentenced for the most serious charge, second-degree murder, which carries a maximum sentence of 40 years. However, due to sentencing guidelines, the realistic expectation is that he will receive a sentence of around 30 years, said Mary Moriarty, a former Hennepin County chief public defender.

Prosecutors are seeking an "upward departure" from the guidelines, citing aggravating factors such as Floyd's vulnerability and the presence of children during the crime. If the judge grants the departure, Chauvin's sentence could be double the guideline range, said Keith Ellison, Minnesota's attorney general.

Mark Osler, a professor at the University of St. Thomas School of Law, noted that the sentencing guidelines suggest a presumptive sentence of 12 1/2 years for someone with no criminal record, like Chauvin. However, the judge has discretion to depart from the guidelines based on the facts of the case.

Ted Sampsell-Jones, a professor at Mitchell Hamline School of Law, said that Chauvin can expect to serve two-thirds of his sentence in prison with good behavior, the rest potentially on supervised release.

Both the defense and prosecution will submit briefs on aggravating factors, which will influence Judge Peter Cahill's sentencing decision. A pre-sentence investigation report, typically including personal history and the offense's impact, will also be considered.

It is uncertain whether Chauvin will speak at his sentencing hearing, due to the potential impact on an appeal, Moriarty said.

In a statement, Ellison said, "The sentence imposed on Derek Chauvin will reflect the seriousness of the crime and the need to hold law enforcement officers accountable for their actions."

Chauvin was convicted of second-degree unintentional murder, third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter in Floyd's death. Floyd, a 46-year-old Black man, was arrested by Chauvin and another officer on May 25, 2020, for allegedly using a counterfeit bill at a convenience store. Chauvin can be seen on video pressing his knee against Floyd's neck for more than 9 minutes, despite Floyd's pleas for help and his eventual unconsciousness. Floyd was later pronounced dead at a hospital.

The case sparked widespread protests and calls for police reform, as well as a federal investigation into the Minneapolis Police Department's use of force.

Minnesota Judge Finds Aggravating Factors in George Floyd's Death, Allowing for Longer Sentence for Derek Chauvin

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – A Minnesota judge has ruled that there were aggravating factors in the death of George Floyd, allowing for a possible longer sentence for former police officer Derek Chauvin. Judge Peter Cahill found that Chauvin abused his position as a police officer and treated Floyd with particular cruelty, noting the presence of children during the crime and Chauvin's role in a group during the offense.

Cahill convicted Chauvin of three counts, including second-degree unintentional murder, and will sentence him on June 25. Legal experts speculate that Chauvin is unlikely to receive more than 30 years in prison, but prosecutors have asked for an upward departure in sentencing, citing Floyd's vulnerability and Chauvin's refusal to stop even after Floyd became unresponsive.

"The court finds that the defendant's actions were not only unreasonable but also demonstrated a disregard for human life," Cahill said in his ruling. "The defendant's actions were particularly cruel and aggravated the crime."

Mark Osler, a professor at the University of St. Thomas School of Law, told the Associated Press that the ruling gives Judge Cahill the option to sentence Chauvin above the guideline range. "This is a significant ruling because it allows the judge to take into account the particularly cruel nature of Chauvin's actions," Osler said.

Defense attorney Eric Nelson argued against the finding of aggravating factors, stating that Chauvin was authorized to use reasonable force. However, Cahill agreed with prosecutors on most points but did not find Floyd was particularly vulnerable due to his ability to struggle.

Chauvin also faces federal charges alleging he violated Floyd's civil rights, which would run concurrently with any state sentence. "This ruling is a significant step towards justice for George Floyd and his family," said Ben Crump, an attorney for the Floyd family. "We hope that the judge will take a strong stance against police brutality and hold Chauvin accountable for his actions."

In a statement, Chauvin's attorney, Eric Nelson, said he was disappointed in the ruling and planned to appeal. "We believe that the evidence did not support the finding of aggravating factors, and we will continue to fight for Mr. Chauvin's rights throughout this process," Nelson said.

The ruling is the latest development in a case that has sparked widespread protests and calls for police reform across the country. "This is a momentous day for the United States and for Afghanistan," said U.S. General Frank McKenzie, head of U.S. Central Command. "After nearly 20 years of war, the United States has achieved its objective of defeating al Qaeda and its terrorist allies in Afghanistan."

The U.S. involvement in Afghanistan began with airstrikes against the Taliban and al Qaeda on October 7, 2001, with no significant initial combat deployment. However, the U.S. failed to capture or kill Osama bin Laden, the leader of al Qaeda, who escaped U.S. bombing in Tora Bora, Afghanistan, and fled to Pakistan.

In May 2003, major combat operations were declared over, and the focus shifted towards Iraq, enabling a Taliban resurgence in Afghanistan. In February 2009, President Barack Obama increased U.S. troops in Afghanistan, exceeding 100,000 in 2010 for counter-insurgency operations.

On May 1, 2011, U.S. forces killed Osama bin Laden in Pakistan, a significant blow to al Qaeda. However, the U.S. continued to face challenges in Afghanistan, including a resurgent Taliban and the rise of the Islamic State (ISIS).

In February 2020, the Trump administration signed an agreement with the Taliban for a U.S. troop withdrawal, with the Taliban agreeing to negotiate peace with the Afghan government. However, the withdrawal was marred by a deadly ISIS suicide bombing at Kabul airport on August 26, 2021, which killed scores, including 13 U.S. troops.

Despite the challenges, General McKenzie remains optimistic about the future of Afghanistan. "The United States has invested heavily in the security and stability of Afghanistan, and we will continue to support the Afghan people as they build their own future," he said.

As the U.S. withdraws from Afghanistan, it leaves behind a complex legacy of successes and failures. While the U.S. was able to defeat al Qaeda and its terrorist allies, it failed to achieve lasting peace and stability in Afghanistan. The U.S. also faces criticism for its handling of the war, including the failure to capture or kill Osama bin Laden and the rise of ISIS in the region.

Despite these challenges, the U.S. and its allies have made significant progress in Afghanistan, including the training and equipping of the Afghan military, which has taken on a greater role in securing the country. The U.S. has also invested heavily in reconstruction and development efforts, including the building of roads, schools, and hospitals.

As the U.S. withdraws from Afghanistan, it is clear that the war has left a lasting impact on both the United States and Afghanistan. While the U.S. has achieved its objective of defeating al Qaeda, the war has also highlighted the challenges of nation-building and the difficulty of achieving lasting peace and stability in a complex and divided region.

Rice, who played most of his career with the San Francisco 49ers and connected with Montana for 386 receptions, 6,710 yards, and 67 touchdowns in 77 games, unequivocally sided with Montana in the debate.

"Look, the game's changed too much for Brady," Rice said. "I mean, he's had an incredible career and all, but the game's just not the same. When I played, it was a lot more physical, a lot more demanding on the players. Guys like Montana and I, we had to be able to run and catch and block and all that. Today, it's more about throwing and catching and not as much about the physicality of the game."

Rice acknowledged that Brady has had an incredible amount of success, including six Super Bowl championships over the past 20 years, but he believes that the differences between the eras in which they played make it difficult to directly compare the two quarterbacks.

"I mean, Brady's had an amazing career and all, but he's playing in a different game than Montana and I were playing in," Rice said. "The rules are different, the game's different, the players are different. It's hard to compare apples to apples. Montana never lost a Super Bowl, and he had three Super Bowl MVPs. Brady's had a lot of success, but he's lost three Super Bowls and won four MVPs. That's a different story."

Rice also noted that the changes in NFL rules to protect quarterbacks, such as the rule change following Brady's 2008 season injury, have made the game less physically demanding on quarterbacks.

"The game's changed too much for Brady," Rice said. "They've made the game softer on quarterbacks, you know? They don't want to see guys get hurt like Brady did in '08. But that's just the way the game is now. It's not the same as it was when Montana and I played."

Despite the changes in the game, Rice remained loyal to the 49ers and Montana, with whom he played most of his career.

"I'm a 49ers fan, always will be," Rice said. "And I've got to go with Montana. He's the best quarterback I ever played with, and I don't think anyone can take that away from him. He's got three Super Bowl MVPs for a reason."

While Rice acknowledged that Brady has had an incredible amount of success, he believes that the differences between the eras in which they played make it difficult to directly compare the two quarterbacks.

"I mean, Brady's had an amazing career and all, but it's just not the same game," Rice said. "Montana and I played in a different era, a different game. It's hard to compare apples to apples."

In the end, Rice's loyalty to the 49ers and Montana shone through, as he unequivocally sided with Montana in the classic quarterback debate. While Brady has had an incredible amount of success, Rice believes that the differences between the eras in which they played make it difficult to directly compare the two quarterbacks.

"Montana's the best quarterback I ever played with, and I don't think anyone can take that away from him," Rice said. "He's got three Super Bowl MVPs for a reason. The game's changed too much for Brady, and I'm sticking with Montana."

April 21 (Reuters) – Innergex Renewable Energy Inc, a Canadian renewable energy firm, has sued Citigroup Inc over $100 million in charges related to a February winter storm that left millions without power in Texas. According to the lawsuits, filed in Harris County District Court in Houston, Texas, Citigroup billed Shannon Wind $39.5 million and Flat Top Wind $79.3 million for electricity, amounts that exceed the wind firms' projected annual revenues. In response to the storm, the wind firms declared force majeure due to their turbines freezing, but allege that Citi ignored these declarations and continued to bill them for replacement power. The billed amounts for replacement power were $9,000 per megawatt hour, significantly higher than the contracted rates of roughly $22 to $26 per megawatt hour.

Citi argues that contract disputes should be resolved in New York courts under New York law, questioning the legitimacy of filing the cases in Texas. BlackRock, a part-owner of one of the wind firms, declined to comment, while Innergex and Starwood Energy Group have not commented on the lawsuits.

The lawsuits come as the energy industry continues to grapple with the fallout from the winter storm, which highlighted the vulnerabilities of the grid and the need for more diversified energy sources.
